Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Flow and Fracture Dynamics in an Ice Shelf Lateral Margin: Observations and Modeling of the McMurdo Shear Zone
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hamilton/1246400

This award supports an integrated field observation, remote sensing and numerical modeling study of the McMurdo Shear Zone (SZ). The SZ is a 5-10 km wide strip of heavily crevassed ice that separates the McMurdo and Ross ice shelves, and is an important region of lateral support for the Ross Ice Shelf. Previous radar and remote sensing studies reveal an enigmatic picture of the SZ in which crevasses detected at depth have no apparent surface expression, and have orientations which are possibly inconsistent with the observed flow field. In the proposed work, we seek to test the hypothesis that the SZ is a zone of chaotic Lagrangian mixing with (intersecting) buried crevasses which leads to rheological instability, potentially allowing large scale velocity discontinuities. The work will involve detailed field-based observations of crevasse distributions and structure using ground-penetrating radar, and GPS and remote sensing observations of the flow and stress field in the SZ. Because of the hazardous nature of the SZ, the radar surveys will be conducted largely with the aid of a lightweight robotic vehicle. Observations will be used to develop a finite element model of ice shelf shear margin behavior. The intellectual merit of this project is an increased understanding of ice shelf shear margin dynamics. Shear margins play a key role in ice shelf stability, and ice shelves in turn modulate the flux of ice from the ice sheet across the grounding line to the ocean. Insights from this project will improve large-scale models being developed to predict ice sheet evolution and future rates of sea level rise, which are topics of enormous societal concern. The broader impacts of the project include an improved basis for US Antarctic Program logistics planning as well as numerous opportunities to engage K-12 students in scientific discovery. Intensified crevassing in the shear zone between the Ross and McMurdo ice shelves would preclude surface crossing by heavy traverse vehicles which would lead to increased costs of delivering fuel to South Pole and a concomitant loss of flight time provided by heavy-lift aircraft for science missions on the continent. Our multidisciplinary research combining glaciology, numerical modeling, and robotics engineering is an engaging way to show how robotics can assist scientists in collecting hazardous field measurements. Our outreach activities will leverage Dartmouth's current NSF GK-12 program, build on faculty-educator relationships established during University of Maine's recent GK-12 program, and incorporate project results into University of Maine's IDEAS initiative, which integrates computational modeling with the existing science curriculum at the middle school level. This award has field work in Antarctica.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The McMurdo Shear Zone (MSZ) is a 5-10 km wide swath of intensely crevassed ice ~ 40 km from McMurdo Station. The 200 km long MSZ bounds the western edge of the Ross Ice Shelf (RIS) and accommodates the transition of rapidly northward flowing ice of the RIS (>1000m/year) with the stationary coast and the smaller McMurdo Ice Shelf (Figure 1).  The large gradients in velocity produce shear resistance along the western edge of RIS that influences the stability of the ice shelf, which in turn controls the stability of the major West Antarctic Ice Sheet. In addition, the active deformation within the MSZ produces intense crevassing and a serious logistical hazard to the primary ice access route from McMurdo Station to the Antarctic interior, the South Pole Traverse (SPoT). Hence, our primary goals were to characterize the origin, number and location of crevasse in the shear zone and their relationship to RIS evolution and stability.

To meet our primary goals, we pursued an integrated strategy of: I. Mapping crevasse distribution with unmanned robotic Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR), in collaboration with Thayer School of Engineering, to identify crevasse distribution and magnitude; II.  Analyzing the ice velocity field of the MSZ to identify potential deformation-related crevassed regions and; III. Applying 3D numerical modeling of the western Ross Ice Shelf to constrain the causes and extent of full thickness ice rifts along the western margin.

In the region of the present SPoT a total of 420 crevasse features were identified from 95km of GPR surveying. The highest crevasse density is associated with the region of steepest lateral velocity gradients and greatest deformation (Figure 2). Along the MSZ, a threshold value of the velocity gradient of ~ 0.0114 /year leads to the initiation of crevassing. We also evaluated each crevasse based on crossing criteria for the MSZ region developed by the Cold Regions Research and Engineering Laboratory (CRREL) researchers: For a crevasse to be deemed safe to cross by a large tracked vehicle, its maximum width cannot exceed the thickness of its overlying snowbridge. Based on this criterion we determined the width to thickness ratio for each crevasse (Figure 3). Our crevasses show a pattern in which the relative size ratio of crevasses appears to increase in the southward direction.

To investigate the overall stability of RIS we used both large scale, whole ice shelf models and smaller scale 3D dynamic models of grounding zone processes and full thickness rifting. The goal of these models is to capture deformation and shelf stability patterns that may influence rifting adjacent to the southern edge of the MSZ at Minna Bluff (Figure 4).  Results of our combined models indicate that focused deformation in the RIS is a consequence of the inherent physics of formation of the ice shelf. Weak zones produced at the grounding line are advected along with the ice and influence rift periodicity not only at this study site, but on other Antarctic ice shelves as well. With projected widespread ice shelf thinning, weak zones will be inherently more likely to produce full thickness rifts, which could lead to destabilization of the greater Antarctic ice sheet system with associated global sea level rise.

Broader Impacts:

The UMaine component of this project has directly supported 1 PhD student, L. Kaluzienski; helped fund research materials for one MSc student, C. Deck, and 1 undergraduate research assistant. As a result of this project, both graduate students are now trained and familiar with the software that underpins large Ice Sheet models and smaller scale 3D models that incorporate both solid and fluid dynamics.  

Results from this work have been published and presented in workshops and to the general public at American Geophysical Union annual meetings, International Glaciological Society annual meetings, short courses and workshops on modeling glacial dynamics.

In addition, our collaboration with Thayer Engineering and CRREL personnel has given Kaluzienski extensive field and geophysical modeling experience with GPR data collection and reduction. Methods of data collection and kinematic analysis developed for this project are being applied to help evaluate safety and logistics for major Antarctic traverses, enhancing the coordination of operational and scientific aspects of U S Antarctic programs.
